summary: influencerintelligence  "Male mental health is really important to me. As I’ve grown up I’ve become so much more aware of how...
caption:
influencerintelligence  “Male mental health is really important to me. As I’ve grown up I’ve become so much more aware of how fragile it is and have come into direct contact with guys who are really struggling and don’t feel comfortable expressing their feelings. This can lead to catastrophic results and It’s such a consistent issue that it’s clear we are currently doing something very wrong. This ties in heavily with toxic masculinity and the repercussions of that for men and women everywhere.” Hit the #linkinbio for our #Spotlight on crazy-talented #actor @edwardbluemel talking about sexual healing, douple-dipping and working with the brilliant @iamsandraohinsta
#onestowatch #emergingtalent #newtalent #risingstar #thehalcyon #adiscoveryofwitches #killingeve #howtobuildagirl #sexeducation #influencermarketing #brandcollaborations #talentcampaigns

What’s next?

I have the second series of ‘A Discovery Of Witches’ coming up to film during 2019. We had so much fun filming the first series so I’m really excited to see everyone again and get back into that. I’d also love to do some more theatre and maybe even try some writing.

blog.name: akalittlevoice

blog.description: LITTLE VOICE. BIG IDEAS. INFINITE POSSIBILITIES. I WANT IT ALL.

title: THE SPY OF MY DREAMS
body:
“Killing Eve” © BBC Pictures; Photo by Robert Viglasky

A Valentine’s Day gift came in the form of a teaser trailer for the second season of Killing Eve. Many, including myself, can’t wait for the April 7th premiere. I personally watched a Killing Eve marathon in December until the wee hours of the morning. It was worth it. I am reminded of how excited everyone was about Sandra Oh’s nominations and wins. I love the show, but I’m more intrigued by Jody Comer’s character, Villanelle. She is smart, funny, witty, cunning, damaged, and an unemotional psychopath with great style.

Sandra Oh’s character Eve reminds me of characters she’s played before (Grey’s Anatomy and Sideways). Smart, dry wit, mixed with a bit of self-doubt and often cutting to those closest to her. I wish the character of Eve was equally self-assured, focused and detached like Villanelle. In a sense, she is detached from her husband and fully focused on Villanelle. And upon a second watching, I saw bits of self-assurance that I had previously missed. For example, after Villanelle steals Eve’s suitcase, Eve suggests that she hates her existing wardrobe anyway, so it’s not exactly a loss. She goes shopping and Villanelle, while stalking Eve, sneaks in an accessory that Eve likes and takes her outfit from blah to Aah! Slowly, Eve begins to show more and more personality similarities to Villanelle. There’s also the moment when Eve’s suitcase is returned and inside it is a black and white dress picked especially for Eve by Villanelle. Trying on the dress, the transformation of Eve continues and swells to an exciting Season 1 conclusion. Thus the anxious anticipation of Season 2.

Image from “Killing Eve” © BBC Pictures

Image from “Killing Eve” © BBC Pictures

How I wish a character like that of Villanelle, could be played by a Black woman. Where is the script for a psychopathic killer, with a great sense of style and dry wit for a Black, Asian or Latina actress? In Season 1, Episode 2 there’s a scene where Villanelle is in the psychiatrist’s office in a bright pink tulle confection, sitting on a jewel-toned blue velvet couch. In a close-up, her face is round, rouged and glowing. She looks sweet and vulnerable, yet she is full of confident deceit. I can easily imagine Janelle Monae’s face in place of Comer’s. I want to see Monae or someone like her in that role — confident, cunning, chameleon-like, stylish and speaking several languages.

Janelle Monae for Allure Magazine; Photo by Camila Falquez


“We wanted people to feel that they could be sitting next to Villanelle on the [London subway] and not notice it, but the next moment she could kill you,” says (Sarah) Barnett. “If you sat next to the Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, you would know it.”


Michaela Coel for Interview Magazine; Photo by Jason Hetherington

Taken from a Variety article with Sarah Barnett, president, and general manager of BBC America — “We wanted people to feel that they could be sitting next to Villanelle on the [London subway] and not notice it, but the next moment she could kill you,” says (Sarah) Barnett. “If you sat next to the Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, you would know it.” I agree. Who among us would ever suspect, sitting next to Janelle Monae, Lizzo, Angela Bassett, Uzo Aduba, Michaela Coel or Tika Sumpter, that they’d be sitting next to an international contract killer and spy — stunning, cunning, ruthless, fluent in several languages, and ice in her veins? I would like to see it.

Credit: John D. Kisch/Separate Cinema Archive/Getty Images

Did you know that Josephine Baker was an operative for the French Resistance during World War II? As an entertainer, Baker traveled freely throughout Europe and smuggled intelligence secrets via invisible ink on her sheet music. She also hid Jewish refugees and weapons in her home in the South of France during this time.

“This invaluable intelligence work eventually helped Baker rise to the rank of lieutenant in the Free French Air Force, and when the war was over she received both the Croix de Guerre (a first for an American woman) and the Medal of the Resistance in 1946.” — Ethan Trex

One might weave a modern tale based on a famous singer who is an undercover spy. Imagine Rihanna or Beyoncé as a modern-day spy. Again, I would like to see it. I can already envision Janelle Monae starring as a spy in a period piece à la Josephine Baker. In the meantime, I’ll settle into a read of Lauren Wilkinson’s American Spy and hope that someone gets the bright idea to make it into a movie.

  • Nylon Magazine review of American Spy: https://nylon.com/lauren-wilkinson-american-spy

tags: probably won't be the only time i write for them
summary: Engulfed - We_Were_Younger - Killing Eve (TV 2018) [Archive of Our Own]
body:
Engulfed - We_Were_Younger - Killing Eve (TV 2018) [Archive of Our Own]

Ship: Eve/Villanelle

Tags: Post S1, Not canon compliant with S2 spoilers, I wrote this months ago and wanted to post it before the new season aired lmao, Implied sexual content, but not explicit, Blood, self-defense killing, suicide mention

Summary:

She selected the un-named number from her contact list. The number that had been forced into her phone only a month prior. She hesitated only a second before pressing the call button, holding the phone to her ear.

It only took a few rings before she heard that chilling and achingly familiar voice.

“Hello?”

Eve closed her eyes as she responded in the faintest of voices she could manage while on the phone. “I need your help.”

 

Eve experiences her first kill

summary: the creators of killing eve saying “we liked making Villanelle’s apartment because it shows that she’s just a typical...
body: the creators of killing eve saying “we liked making Villanelle’s apartment because it shows that she’s just a typical twenty-something!!! with a typical twenty-something apartment!!! but she happens to be an assassin!!!!” is the most pretentious thing i’ve ever read as a twenty-something with multiple jobs, living with my parents cos that’s all i can afford and so do most twenty-somethings i know. there’s nothing really typically twenty-something about Villanelle’s multi-million dollar apartment filled with things she can afford cos she’s loaded ????? anyway wouldn’t it be nice to be well off ??? imagine…
